elements.content: When reacted with europium nitrate under mild conditions, all-cis 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (H6L cis ) retains its configuration and gives the complexes [Eu(H3L cis )(H2O)4]·xH2O with x = 3 (1) or 6 (2). In both cases, the three carboxylate groups are in the equatorial position and the carboxylic groups are axial. The carboxylate groups are all chelating in 1, thus giving a hexagonal, two-dimensional network; one group is chelating, one bridging bidentate and the other monodentate in 2, and the resulting two-dimensional assembly displays a tetragonal arrangement. Under hydrothermal conditions with prolonged heating at 180 °C, H6L undergoes isomerization into the all-trans form, resulting in the formation of [Eu2(L trans )(H2O)8]·4H2O (3). All six carboxylate groups are in equatorial position, four of them being chelating and the other two monodentate; the former gives rise to planar ribbon-like subunits, which are assembled into a three-dimensional framework of rutile-type topology by the latter. Complex 3 was also obtained from in situ hydrolysis, oxidation, and isomerization of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride. Compounds 1−3 are the first lanthanide ion complexes with the ligand H6−x L x−.

In both cases, the three carboxylate groups are in the equatorial position and the carboxylic groups are axial. The carboxylate groups are all chelating in 1, thus giving a hexagonal, two-dimensional network; one group is chelating, one bridging bidentate and the other monodentate in 2, and the resulting two-dimensional assembly displays a tetragonal arrangement. Under hydrothermal conditions with prolonged heating at 180 °C, H6L undergoes isomerization into the all-trans form, resulting in the formation of [Eu2(L trans )(H2O)8]⋅4H2O (3). All six carboxylate groups are in equatorial position, four of them being chelating and the other two monodentate; the former gives rise to planar ribbon-like subunits, which are assembled into a three-dimensional framework of rutile-type topology by the latter. Complex 3 was also obtained from in situ hydrolysis, oxidation, and isomerization of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride. Compounds 1-3 are the first lanthanide ion complexes with the ligand H6-x L x-.

elements.content: Depending on the experimental conditions, the hexacarboxylic acid either retains its original, all-cis configuration or undergoes isomerization into the all-trans form. This, together with a different deprotonation degree, has a marked influence on the assemblies formed, two-dimensional in the former case and three-dimensional in the latter.

elements.content: Among polycarboxylic acids, which are choice ligands for the synthesis of f-element−organic polymers and frameworks, those possessing six carboxylic groups, hence 12 potential donor atoms, display the most outstanding denticity and assembling power. Several lanthanide−organic frameworks built from the more obvious ligand in this group, benzenehexacarboxylic acid (mellitic acid), were reported. In contrast, no 4f element ion complex of its alicyclic counterpart, 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (denoted H6L hereafter), has been crystallographically characterized, apart from the heterometallic uranyl−lanthanide complexes [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]·H2O (Ln = Pr, Eu, Tb, Er) recently reported, in which [Ln(H2O)7]3+ groups decorate the two sides of the two-dimensional {[UO2(HL)]3−}∞ assembly. These are the first uranyl complexes with this ligand, and they are among the rare heterometallic uranyl−lanthanide complexes known. More generally, H6L has not been very widely used as a ligand, and a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.31) gives only a score of d-block element ion complexes. This ligand, which is always found in the chair conformation, is known to undergo isomerization during metal complexation under hydrothermal conditions, with in particular the transformation of the initial all-cis form (H6L cis ), with the carboxylic groups alternately in equatorial and axial positions on the cyclohexane ring, into the all-trans one (H6L trans ), in which all groups are in the equatorial position (other minor isomers can also be isolated, depending upon the reaction conditions). Up to now, the only complexes with the all-cis form are those of silver(I) and uranyl ions. We report herein the syntheses and crystal structures of the first homometallic lanthanide complexes with both H6L cis and H6L trans , the latter being generated in situ either directly from H6L cis or using bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride as a starting material.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Among polycarboxylic acids, which are choice ligands for the synthesis of f-element-organic polymers and frameworks, those possessing six carboxylic groups, hence 12 potential donor atoms, display the most outstanding denticity and assembling power. Several lanthanide-organic frameworks built from the more obvious ligand in this group, benzenehexacarboxylic acid (mellitic acid), were reported. In contrast, no 4f element ion complex of its alicyclic counterpart, 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (denoted H6L hereafter), has been crystallographically characterized, apart from the heterometallic uranyl-lanthanide complexes [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]⋅H2O (Ln = Pr, Eu, Tb, Er) recently reported, in which [Ln(H2O)7]3+ groups decorate the two sides of the two-dimensional {[UO2(HL)]3-}∞ assembly. These are the first uranyl complexes with this ligand, and they are among the rare heterometallic uranyl-lanthanide complexes known. More generally, H6L has not been very widely used as a ligand, and a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.31) gives only a score of d-block element ion complexes. This ligand, which is always found in the chair conformation, is known to undergo isomerization during metal complexation under hydrothermal conditions, with in particular the transformation of the initial all-cis form (H6L cis ), with the carboxylic groups alternately in equatorial and axial positions on the cyclohexane ring, into the all-trans one (H6L trans ), in which all groups are in the equatorial position (other minor isomers can also be isolated, depending upon the reaction conditions). Up to now, the only complexes with the all-cis form are those of silver(I) and uranyl ions. We report herein the syntheses and crystal structures of the first homometallic lanthanide complexes with both H6L cis  and H6L trans , the latter being generated in situ either directly from H6L cis  or using bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride as a starting material.

Elemental analyses were performed by Service de Microanalyse du CNRS at Gif-sur-Yvette, France.

Experimental Section

Synthesis

 all-cis-1,2,3,4,5,6-Cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid monohydrate, bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride, and europium nitrate pentahydrate were purchased from Aldrich. Elemental analyses were performed by Service de Microanalyse du CNRS at Gif-sur-Yvette, France.

elements.content: H6L cis ·H2O (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), Eu(NO3)3·5H2O (43 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 30 min). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 1 appeared within one week (9.0 mg, 14% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C12H23EuO19: C, 23.13; H, 3.72. Found: C, 23.14; H, 3.57%.

Complex 3 was obtained from two different experiments, with different ligands as starting materials.

(a) H6L cis ·H2O (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), Eu(NO3)3·5H2O (43 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding colorless crystals of complex 3 in very low yield within two weeks (∼2 mg, ∼5% yield based on Eu). elements.content: The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps (except for those of the solvent water molecule in 3), and all the others were introduced at calculated positions; all were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. The absolute configuration in 1 was determined from the value of the Flack parameter, −0.030(10).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps (except for those of the solvent water molecule in 3), and all the others were introduced at calculated positions; all were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. The absolute configuration in 1 was determined from the value of the Flack parameter, -0.030(10).

Symmetry codes: 1 ′ = x, y, z + 1; ′′ = x + 1, y, z + 1. 2 ′ = 1 − x, −y, −z; ′′ = x − 1, y, z; ′′′ = 1 − x, −y, 1 − z. 3 ′′ = x − 1/2, 1/2 − y, z − 1/2.

Complexes 1 and 2, [Eu(H3L cis )(H2O)4]·3H2O and [Eu(H3L cis )(H2O)4]·6H2O, respectively, were both obtained from evaporation of an aqueous solution at room temperature, after a brief duration of heating to ensure complete dissolution. As expected, the all-cis configuration is retained in both cases. The overall formulas differ only in the number of uncoordinated water molecules, but the coordination mode of the ligand is different in the two complexes, probably as a result of the presence of NaOH in the synthesis of 1, although the mechanism is unclear; in particular, the deprotonation degree is the same in both complexes. It is also notable that complex 1 crystallized more readily, while crystals of 2 were obtained only after one month.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 all-cis Complexes

Complexes 1 and 2, [Eu(H3L cis )(H2O)4]⋅3H2O and [Eu(H3L cis )(H2O)4]⋅6H2O, respectively, were both obtained from evaporation of an aqueous solution at room temperature, after a brief duration of heating to ensure complete dissolution. As expected, the all-cis configuration is retained in both cases. The overall formulas differ only in the number of uncoordinated water molecules, but the coordination mode of the ligand is different in the two complexes, probably as a result of the presence of NaOH in the synthesis of 1, although the mechanism is unclear; in particular, the deprotonation degree is the same in both complexes. It is also notable that complex 1 crystallized more readily, while crystals of 2 were obtained only after one month.

elements.content: In both compounds, the asymmetric unit comprises one metal ion and one 3-fold deprotonated ligand in an all-cis configuration and in a chair conformation, with the three carboxylate groups in the equatorial position and the three carboxylic groups in the axial position (Figures a and a). The planes defined by the three carboxylate groups are close to the mean plane of the cyclohexane ring, with dihedral angles in the range 13.8−26.6°. This is an ideal geometry to ensure the formation of a planar assembly through these groups, whereas the carboxylic acid groups form three intramolecular hydrogen bonds, each with an oxygen atom from one of the carboxylate groups as acceptor (Table ). Such intramolecular hydrogen bonds, albeit not involving all the protonated groups, are also present in the structures of H6L cis ·3H2O and [Ag3(H3L cis )(H2O)2]·2H2O, whereas one hydrogen bond between two axial, uncoordinated groups is found in [UO2Ln(HL cis )(H2O)7]·H2O. In the chiral structure of 1, each of the three carboxylate groups chelates a europium ion (Scheme ), with an average Eu−O bond length of 2.59(21) Å (Table ), the large population standard deviation being indicative of the strong asymmetry of the chelation, with a difference between the two bonds as large as 0.62 Å for atoms O1 and O2. Curiously, the three atoms giving the shortest bond lengths (O1, O5 and O9) are those involved in intramolecular hydrogen bonds. The average Eu−O bond length is larger than that of 2.476(12) Å in the uranyl−europium complex reported previously, as well as that of 2.49(6) Å for similar bonds in the CSD. The europium coordination sphere is completed by four water molecules, with an average Eu−O bond length of 2.45(3) Å, identical to that in the heterometallic complex and to the mean value of 2.44(7) Å from the CSD. The 10-coordinate europium environment geometry is distorted bicapped square antiprismatic, which is the most stable arrangement for this coordination number. The two square faces are defined by atoms O1, O9′′, O13, O14 and O2, O6′, O15, O16 [dihedral angle between the two faces 11.38(7)°], and O5′ and O10′′ are in capping positions [O5′−Eu−O10′′ 153.11(10)°]. Both metal ion and ligand being trigonal nodes, a two-dimensional hexagonal assembly parallel to (0 1 0) and with the point symbol (63) is formed (Figure b), which is analogous to that formed with uranyl ions in [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]·H2O. All the carboxylic groups are on the same side of the layers and point toward the same direction in the crystal. The layers are offset with respect to one another (Figure c) so that no extended channel is formed and they are held together by hydrogen bonds involving both coordinated and free water molecules. The packing is quite compact, with a Kitaigorodski packing index, estimated with PLATON, of 0.78 (0.69 with solvent molecules excluded) leaving no appreciable free space.

The bonding scheme in complex 2 is quite different since only one carboxylate group is chelating, in a manner which is also very asymmetric [average bond length 2.61(10) Å]; in this case also, the shortest bond corresponds to the oxygen atom involved in an intramolecular hydrogen bond. The carboxylate group comprising O5 and O6 is bidentate and bridging between two cations and that comprising O9 and O10 is monodentate (Scheme ), with an overall Eu−O bond length of 2.400(16) Å in agreement with the mean value of 2.40(6) Å from the CSD. The europium coordination sphere is completed by four water molecules [average bond length 2.427(18) Å] and the nine-coordinate environment geometry is capped square antiprismatic, with the two square faces defined by atoms O1, O5′, O13, O14 and O6′′, O9′′′, O15, O16 [dihedral angle between the two faces 4.73(9)°], and with O2 in capping position. Each metal atom is thus bound to four ligands, while each ligand connects four metal atoms. The resulting assembly is two-dimensional and parallel to (0 1 0), but its topology is different from that in 1, with the total point symbol (44, 62), the two nodes being identically connected in the tetragonal network (Figure b). The axial, uncoordinated carboxylic groups are pointing on either side of the layers (Figure c), and an extended network of hydrogen bonds, involving both the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules, is formed (Table ). The packing index amounts to 0.80 (0.62 with solvent molecules excluded) and it is thus close to that in 1.

As previously indicated, the cis-trans isomerization of the ligand H6L is commonly observed when hydrothermal conditions are used. A similar isomerization process has also been observed previously with other polyacids, such as 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid or 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylic acid, which undergoes at least a partial transformation of the cis,trans,cis form into the trans,trans,trans form under hydrothermal conditions. A possible mechanism for these transformations in the presence of bases involves acid−base equilibria with formation of enolate ions. Analogously, the formation of enols can account for the isomerization in acidic media. In the case of the hexaacid H6L, a large number of isomers can be produced, but the equilibrium is generally shifted toward the all-trans isomer, with all carboxylic groups in equatorial position; the latter isomer has been estimated to be more stable than the all-cis one by about 33.5 kJ mol−1, but obviously the relative stability is expected to change in the case of deprotonated and/or complexed species. The only complexes of the all-cis form with d-block metal ions have been obtained at room temperature, but the all-cis configuration was retained in the uranyl−lanthanide complexes, notwithstanding the use of hydrothermal conditions with heating durations as long as 10 days. In keeping with the previously published observations, heating the solution of H6L cis and europium nitrate in the presence of NaOH at 180 °C for two weeks gave crystals of [Eu2(L trans )(H2O)8]·4H2O (3). The same complex was serendipitously obtained when a solution of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride and europium nitrate, with no base added, was heated at 180 °C for six weeks. We found that the one-pot transformation of the above anhydride into H6L cis is a well-known synthetic procedure, involving, according to Scheme : (i) hydrolysis of the dianhydride and formation of the tetracarboxylic acid (H4L1); (ii) oxidation with bond breaking of H4L1 and formation of H6L cis ; (iii) isomerization with formation of H6L trans and of other isomers. It is interesting to compare typical conditions used in the literature procedure (70% HNO3 and NH4VO3, at 50−60 °C for 15 h) with the conditions we used [Eu(NO3)3 in water, at 180 °C for 6 weeks]. In our case, the nitrate ion possibly works as an oxidant, while Eu(III) possibly works both as an oxidant and as a catalyst. The final isomerization appears to take place even in the absence of added bases or acids, a previous example of this behavior being reported in the case of a complex with Cd(II). Recent studies have shown that, in some cases, different compounds can be obtained from a ligand when either used directly or generated in situ, but the same complex is obtained from both routes in the present case.

all-trans Complex

A similar isomerization process has also been observed previously with other polyacids, such as 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid or 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylic acid, which undergoes at least a partial transformation of the cis,trans,cis form into the trans,trans,trans form under hydrothermal conditions. elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in a more highly symmetric space group than the two former complexes; the asymmetric unit comprises a europium atom located on the mirror plane (x y 0), one-fourth of the fully deprotonated ligand, three coordinated water molecules (two of them on the symmetry plane) and one free water molecule (Figure a). The ligand, in the chair conformation and with all carboxylate groups in equatorial positions, is centrosymmetric and it sits on a mirror plane containing atoms C3, C4, O3, O4 and their images by symmetry; in consequence, a binary axis bisects the C2−C2′′′ segment and its image by symmetry. The dihedral angles between the planes of the carboxylate groups and the mean plane of the cyclohexane ring are 64.3 and 90°, the latter value for the group located on the mirror plane; these values are much larger than those in 1 and 2, and are indicative of the larger steric hindrance in the all-trans isomer. Four out of the six carboxylate groups are chelating, in a much more symmetric manner than in 1 and 2, with an average Eu−O bond length of 2.50(3) Å. The two remaining groups, located on the mirror plane, are monodentate (Scheme ), with a shorter Eu−O bond length of 2.352(9) Å comparable to those in 2 and the CSD. A similar bonding mode is found with the aromatic counterpart of H6L, mellitic acid, in some of its lanthanide ion complexes, and a tetrakis(chelating), bis(monodentate) bonding mode is found in some complexes of L6− with d-block metal ions, but the relative positions of the sites on the ring and/or the configuration are different from those in 3. The europium coordination sphere in 3 is completed by four water molecules [Eu−O bond length 2.449(11) Å]. The coordination environment is a quite regular capped square antiprism, with one square face defined by the carboxylate atoms O1, O2, O1′, O2′ and the other by the four water molecules [dihedral angle between the two faces 6.7(5)°], and with the carboxylate atom O3′′ in capping position. The ligand in 3 assumes a more highly efficient assembling role than in 1 and 2, being a hexagonal node, while the metal ion is only connected to three ligands. Bonding by the four equivalent chelating carboxylate groups gives rise to planar ribbon-like subunits of alternate ligands and groups of two cations, running along the c axis direction. The monodentate carboxylate groups located on either side of these subunits ensure further linking of the ribbons, offset by half a c axis parameter length and tilted with respect to one another. A three-dimensional framework is thus created (Figure b,c), displaying flat channels extending along the c axis direction, with a section of approximate dimension 9 × 4 Å2 (ca. 6 × 1 Å2 when atomic radii are subtracted), which are occupied by the hydrogen bonded uncoordinated water molecules. The packing index amounts to 0.73 (0.66 with solvent excluded). The total point symbol for the binodal network is (4, 62)2(42, 610, 83), which corresponds to the quite common rutile topological type, with the roles of metal and ligand interchanged. The particular role of the monodentate atom O3 in the formation of this network is noteworthy; if all carboxylate groups were chelating, the more natural outcome (although not the necessary one) would be a planar two-dimensional assembly, in keeping with all the groups being in equatorial positions (this arrangement could however be prevented by steric hindrance), and it is through the out-of-plane coordination of O3 that the network is extended into a three-dimensional framework, the bonding geometry of the ligand being thus topologically octahedral (Figure ).

elements.content: We have reported herein the first crystal structures of lanthanide ion complexes with both the all-cis and all-trans configurations of 3- or 6-fold deprotonated 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid, the all-cis form being obtained upon brief heating and evaporation at room temperature and the all-trans one through prolonged heating under hydrothermal conditions. The large assembling potential of this ligand is only partially fulfilled in complexes 1 and 2, with the all-cis form of the tricarboxylate, H3L cis 3−, which are two-dimensional assemblies with hexagonal or tetragonal patterns, respectively, with either chelation of three metal ions (as in the case of the uranyl ion) or a mixture of chelation and monodentate bonding to four cations, by the three coordination sites in equatorial positions. In contrast, the all-trans form L trans 6−, in which all the carboxylic groups are deprotonated and in the equatorial position, connects six metal centers, four of them being chelated to give rise to a planar ribbon-like subunit and the other two being bound in monodentate fashion, so that a three-dimensional framework is generated. Apart from being the first lanthanide ion complexes with this ligand, the present compounds give a further example of in situ isomerization of H6L. As in the previously reported case of 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylic acid, this appears to be a useful way of completely changing the coordinating mode of a given ligand toward one metal cation and to obtain widely different networks or frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have reported herein the first crystal structures of lanthanide ion complexes with both the all-cis and all-trans configurations of 3- or 6-fold deprotonated 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid, the all-cis form being obtained upon brief heating and evaporation at room temperature and the all-trans one through prolonged heating under hydrothermal conditions. The large assembling potential of this ligand is only partially fulfilled in complexes 1 and 2, with the all-cis form of the tricarboxylate, H3L cis  3-, which are two-dimensional assemblies with hexagonal or tetragonal patterns, respectively, with either chelation of three metal ions (as in the case of the uranyl ion) or a mixture of chelation and monodentate bonding to four cations, by the three coordination sites in equatorial positions. In contrast, the all-trans form L trans  6-, in which all the carboxylic groups are deprotonated and in the equatorial position, connects six metal centers, four of them being chelated to give rise to a planar ribbon-like subunit and the other two being bound in monodentate fashion, so that a three-dimensional framework is generated. Apart from being the first lanthanide ion complexes with this ligand, the present compounds give a further example of in situ isomerization of H6L. As in the previously reported case of 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylic acid, this appears to be a useful way of completely changing the coordinating mode of a given ligand toward one metal cation and to obtain widely different networks or frameworks.

H6L cis ·H2O (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), Eu(NO3)3·5H2O (43 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 30 min). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 1 appeared within one week (9.0 mg, 14% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C12H23EuO19: C, 23.13; H, 3.72. Found: C, 23.14; H, 3.57%.

[Eu(H<sub>3</sub>L<sub> <italic toggle="yes">cis</italic> </sub>)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]·6H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

H6L cis ·H2O (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), Eu(NO3)3·5H2O (43 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 30 min). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 2 appeared within one month (16 mg, 24% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C12H29EuO22: C, 21.28; H, 4.32. Found: C, 21.37; H, 4.32%.

[Eu<sub>2</sub>(L<sub> <italic toggle="yes">trans</italic> </sub>)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 was obtained from two different experiments, with different ligands as starting materials.

(a) H6L cis ·H2O (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), Eu(NO3)3·5H2O (43 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) and demineralized water (1.2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding colorless crystals of complex 3 in very low yield within two weeks (∼2 mg, ∼5% yield based on Eu). No other material was obtained.

(b) Bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), Eu(NO3)3·5H2O (43 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (2.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding colorless crystals of complex 3 within six weeks (8.0 mg, 19% yield based on Eu). Anal. Calcd. for C12H30Eu2O24: C, 16.72; H, 3.51. Found: C, 16.96; H, 3.23%.

Symmetry codes: ′ = x, y, −z; ′′ = x − 1/2, 1/2 − y, z − 1/2; ′′′ = 1 − x, −y, z; ′′′′ = x, y, 1 − z; # = 1 − x, −y, 1 − z; ## = x + 1/2, 1/2 − y, z + 1/2; ̂= 1/2 − x, y − 1/2, 1/2 − z. (b) and (c) Two views of the three-dimensional framework. The europium coordination polyhedra are shown; solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted.
